thread.title: Mustafa Farah murder trial: Gasps in court as basketball player cleared of young man's murder
thread.title_full: Mustafa Farah murder trial: Gasps in court as basketball player cleared of young man's murder

author: Tom Powell
title: Mustafa Farah murder trial: Gasps in court as basketball player cleared of young man's murder
text:
35   Walked free: former London Paws player Elmi Awil 
A budding basketball star has been cleared of murdering a man by battering him around the neck with part of a shopping trolley. 
Elmi Awil, 21, who is 6ft 7in tall, was accused of attacked Mustafa Farah, 24, with a metal bar after a row erupted between two groups in the early hours of Saturday June 4 last year. 
The former London Paws player, who has had basketball trials in the US, claimed he acted in self-defence. 
He was found not guilty of murder and an alternative charge of the manslaughter of 6ft 4in Mr Farah in Willesden High Road, north-west London. 
As the verdict was delivered after nearly 12 hours of deliberations, members of the dead man's family gasped, with one exclaiming "what justice?" before walking out of the Old Bailey courtroom. Victim: Mustafa Farah 
According to a local cafe owner who tried to defuse the situation, Mr Farah was "out of it" before Brunel University student Awil hit him with a distinctive red and blue pole, the court heard. 
The cafe owner described a tall man with an iron bar being "egged on" while another man was heard to say: "He's not worth it. He's drunk. Let's just leave it." 
Mr Farah, who was of Somali heritage and lived in Camden with his family, collapsed in the street and died in hospital eight days later. 
Pathologist Ashley Fegan-Earl found he had suffered a heart attack as a result of being struck in the vagus nerve in the neck, something he had only seen three times in 17,000 post-mortem examinations. A shopping trolley handle allegedly used as in the fight 
After the fight, 20-year-old Abukar Yahye drove Awil to Victoria Coach Station from where he fled to the Netherlands, the court heard. Days later, he returned to England and handed himself in to police. 
The weapon, a 50cm long shopping trolley bar, was retrieved by police from a wheelie bin. The court heard that two fingerprints on it matched Awil's right hand. Read more
